episode_title: How She Makes $300K/Year with Self-Storage with Lauren Rothlisberger

ï»¿Nik (00:00.851)
All right, Lauren, welcome to Niconomics.

hey, thanks for having me. It's good to be on.


Nik (00:07.751)
Awesome. Well, let's just hop into it. Tell me what is your business and how do you make


Lauren Rothlisberger (00:12.718)
So as I wrote you earlier about this, I'm in self storage. also, we won't really talk about it. I also have a dumpster roll off business and those kind of went hand in hand. But the one I think we'll focus on today is self storage, which I've been doing for longer.


Nik (00:27.197)
Okay, so I'm excited to talk about self storage because I think that real estate Twitter and SMB Twitter have fetishized the self storage space. And we're going to get to like all the reasons why. But I want to first start by asking, how did you get into this because you have a really, really interesting


Lauren Rothlisberger (00:47.406)
So the pretty short version is I'm a military spouse. We've moved all over the country slash world for the last 20 years I knew I wanted to get into real estate just on the residential side because I had had family members that bought did it and I kind of had the mindset like just buy something every time we move and You know, and then we'll take that investment and you know hold it and and so we did that But as I started to learn about commercial real estate, I was like, you know, this just seems like this is the next place I want to go with this


And so eventually we have sold off all of those homes and then put it into commercial real estate. So that's kind of a slow ramp up. But over the last few years, I've really kind of gone full time into that and that's been great.


Nik (01:30.229)
Cool. On the self storage side, can you give an idea, just some perspective on how big are your holdings currently? I don't even know how to measure the self storage. Do you do it on number of units? Is it by revenue?


Lauren Rothlisberger (01:41.454)
yeah. So you could obviously do it on any of those. I, number of units is popular or square footage is popular. I, I do number of units just because it's a little bit easier for me to calculate out. I have a tiny, tiny portfolio compared to many, many people, but, you know, I've got like 350 units or something like that. So it's, it's very small. you know, there's lots of people on Twitter with thousands and thousands of units. what's interesting is that I'm actually.


They're in a better place because it's totally in economies of scale. So like there's places where I'll expand eventually and add more units and that it's better to be bigger. But getting my foot in the door, that's kind of where I landed right


Nik (02:24.597)
Yeah, and you said that there's lots of people who own thousands of units. You own 350, which to me sounds like a ton of units. Talk about the business in particular. What exactly is self storage?


Lauren Rothlisberger (02:38.956)
Yeah, so I mean, it's interesting because the product base is really different. So when you talk about self storage, you've got like your class a super nice climate controlled. Some of them you can drive into. they're sort of like the four seasons. And then you've got all the way down to just like drive up kind of, you know, gravel lots, maybe a little more like a days and Motel six style. but they're both do really well. Those are two totally different client bases and they're looking for different things. Like I have drive up storage.


you know, that's easier to get into when you acquire, if you want to put something really nice in there, I will be the first person to tell you, this is not the place for you. Go somewhere else with some climate control. so I mean, that's kind of essentially what you're doing, right? You've got a space, different, very, you know, variations of unit sizes and then people, you know, rent them for you. It's a month to month basis. So it's kind of nice because pricing is very dynamic. you don't have, you don't have long leases and you spread the risk some over.


the number of tenants, right? So it's a pain in the neck to have hundreds or thousands of tenants, but you're also not going to have a huge, massive tenant exit where you go to zero likely overnight. So that was actually one of the things that I liked a lot when I was looking at the business is I'm not afraid of risk, but I'm also like trying to make sure it's smart. So to me at that time, I was like, okay, this, this, this makes me feel more comfortable because I feel like I can buy something and you know, I, won't lose everybody all at once. Even if I raise a rent or if I,


Once I figured it out. So those are all the things that kind of attracted

Yep.

Almost every state makes you like tow it and it's a whole complication. So, yeah, I think, you know, it's.


you're likely to not really discover anything great, but sometimes, you know, we discover some decent stuff and it sells well in an auction.

was
